Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Story:
I was deep into debugging a tricky piece of code when I heard my dog barking in the hallway again. The sound echoed through the shared corridor, and I winced, imagining Mrs. Lee from next door sighing in frustration. She’d already mentioned how the barking startled her when she came home from work. I knew I should be more considerate, maybe keep my dog away from the door or train him better, but my mind was already tangled in work.

At the same time, an email pinged: the product team was holding a brainstorming session next sprint. Attendance was optional, but I knew my input would help shape the new features. I also knew that if I didn’t show up, I might miss a chance to collaborate and influence the direction of our project. But the session was scheduled right when my dog usually got restless, and I’d need to keep an eye on him to avoid more hallway incidents.

I felt the pressure mounting—my neighbors expected peace and respect for our shared space, while my team expected me to be present and engaged. I sat at my desk, torn between the two worlds, unsure which demand to answer first.
